child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: In addition to the 8 dialect groups under Chinese shown in this tree, the author also listed "Certain Isolated Groups", which comprised of "dialects spoken in the southern part of Anhui, certain dialects in Hunan and in the northeastern part of Guangxi" (Li 1973: 5).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "Settlements of speakers of the Southern group (Amoy, Swatow, Hainan, etc.) may be found in large number in Formosa, Indo-China, Burma, Siam, Malay Peninsula, and the South Seas" (Li 1973: 4).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: The author listed Amoy, Swatow and Hainan under the Southern Min group, and made reference to the existence of additional dialects (Li 1973: 4).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "The Hainan dialects of the Southern group possess many phonetic peculiarities, possibly under the influence of aboriginal speech, presumably a Tai language" (Li 1973: 4). The author listed Amoy, Swatow and Hainan under the Southern Min group, and made reference to the existence of additional dialects (Li 1973: 4).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: The author listed Amoy, Swatow and Hainan under the Southern Min group, and made reference to the existence of additional dialects (Li 1973: 4).

child.geography: Southern part of Fujian, Eastern part of Guangdong, Hainan Island, parts of the Leizhou Peninsula

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.geography: Northern part of Fujian

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "The Wu group of dialects is spoken south of the Yangtze in Jiangsu, Zhejiang, and in a few districts in the eastern part of Jiangxi" (Li 1973: 4).
child.geography: South of the Yangtze in Jiangsu, Zhejiang, and in a few districts in the eastern part of Jiangxi

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "The Northern Mandarin group occupies a large area in North China, in the provinces of Hebei, Shanxi, Shanxi, Gansu, Henan, and Shandong, and extends into Xinjiang, Inner Mongolia, and Manchuria in the north, and into Hubei, Anhui, and in Jiangsu in the south" (Li 1973: 3).
child.geography: North China, in the provinces of Hebei, Shanxi, Shanxi, Gansu, Henan, and Shandong, and extends into Xinjiang, Inner Mongolia, and Manchuria in the north, and into Hubei, Anhui, and in Jiangsu in the south

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "The Gan-Hakka group is spoken principally in the provinces of Jiangxi and Guangdong" (Li 1973: 4).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "Settlements of Hakka people can be found in various districts in Guangdong, and Guangxi, and in South-east Asia, and the South Seas" (Li 1973: 4).
child.geography: Guangdong and Guanxi, Southeast Asia, South Seas

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.

child.geography: Jiangxi and Guangdong

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "Settlements of speakers of this group can be found in large numbers in Southeast Asia and the South Seas" (Li 1973: 4).
child.geography: Provinces of Guangdong and Guangxi

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "The Eastern Mandarin group is spoken along the lower Yangtze in the provinces of Anhui and Jiangsu" (Li 1973: 3).
child.geography: Along the lower Yangtze in the provinces of Anhui and Jiangsu

child.pub-comments: "The Southwestern Mandarin group is a fairly uniform type of speech spoken in Sichuan, Yunnan, Guizhou, and parts of Hubei and Guangxi" (Li 1973: 3).
child.geography: Sichuan, Yunnan, Guizhou, and parts of Hubei and Guangxi

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "The Kam-Tai branch is proposed by the author to include the Tai languages on the one hand and the Kam-Sui languages on the other. The term Tai is used here in a narrow sense and does not include languages whose kinship has not been sufficiently clarified, such as Annamite (studied by Maspero) and Miao-Yao (studied by Schmidt). The Kam-Sui languages, on the other hand, can be shown to be definitively related to the Tai, but must be separated from Primitive Tai sufficiently early to develop their particular features, while the Tai languages have developed fairly uniformly" (Li 1973: 5).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: The author divided this group into five "subdivisions" (Li 1973: 6).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: Node not named by author. The author listed Thai Blanc, Nung, and Tho under this group, and made reference to the existence of additional languages (Li 1973: 6).

child.pub-comments: "The language of Shu Li, spoken in the northern part of Hainan Island, in Ling-gao, Chengmai, and Qiongshan belongs here also, but the Li languages in the center and in the south of the island seem to show great divergence from the rest of the Tai languages. Their relation to this group is therefore doubtful " (Li 1973: 6).
child.geography: Center and south of Hainan island

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "The language of Shu Li, spoken in the northern part of Hainan Island, in Ling-gao, Chengmai, and Qiongshan belongs here also, but the Li languages in the center and in the south of the island seem to show great divergence from the rest of the Tai languages" (Li 1973: 6).
child.geography: Northern part of Hainan island, Ling-gao, Chengmai, and Qiongshan

child.pub-comments: "The eastern dailects, the Khams and the Jarong, preserve the prefixes and final consonants very faithfully" (Li 1973: 8).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "The Central dialects, including that of Lhasa, are characterized by the loss of prefixes, simplification of consonant clusters, and the dropping of final consonants" (Li 1973: 8).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.

child.pub-comments: "Minkia may possibly belong to this group, but it shows strong Chinese influence in its vocabulary and word order, and its relationship remains doubtful" (Li 1973: 9).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.

"Lolo and its dialects is spoken in a large protion of Yunnan, in northwestern Guizhou, and in southern Sichuan and Xikang. It extends into Indo-China and Thailand." (p. 9)

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "Speakers of the various languages of the Burmese group, Burmese Kuki-Chin, and 'Old Kuki', etc. are found mostely in Burma and Assam" (Li 1973: 9).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: The author listed Burmese, Burmese Kuki-Chin and Old Kuki under Tibeto-Burman group, and made reference to the existence of additional subgroups (Li 1973: 9).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.

child.pub-comments: "The Maio group is spoken under various tribal names in the western mountain regions of Hunan, a large part Guizhou, and is found scattered here and there in northern Guangxi, southern Sichuan, Yunnan, Indo-China and Thailand" (Li 1973: 7).
child.geography: Western mountain regions of Hunan, a large part Guizhou, northern Guangxi, southern Sichuan, Yunnan, Indo-China and Thailand

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: "The Yao group is also spoken under various tribal names in the northwestern mountain regions of Guangdong, in southern Guizhou, and is scattered here and there among various mountain regions of Guangxi, Yunnan, Indo-China, and Thailand" (Li 1973: 7).

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1973. Languages and Dialects of China, Journal of Chinese Linguistics, vol. 1, 1-13. Berkeley: Project on Linguistics Analysis.
child.pub-comments: According to the author, Annamite (Vietnamese) may be included in the Yao group, although "it shows strong affinities with the Mon-Khmer languages" (Li 1973: 8).

child.geography: Northwestern mountain regions of Guangdong, southern Guizhou, mountain regions of Guangxi, Yunnan, Indo-China and Thailand
